comments: It looks like there is no comprehensive resource on how to put together the editors generated by EMF and GMF. I've already got the basic setup working (see http://www.volker-wegert.de/emf-gmf-integration), but both the implementation and the article itself need some polishing. I'd volunteer to write the article if enough people are interested in it.

I've added gmf.docs-inbox@eclipse.org to the CC list in hopes that somebody from GMF can comment on this bug. Ideally, we'd like a committer to commit to reviewing and approving this article. Any takers?

We can review. Note the linked article clearly says it is not done yet, so this Bugzilla looks more like a "should I do an article" rather than "I have an article for review". Let me know if I am incorrect.

(In reply to comment #2)
> We can review. Note the linked article clearly says it is not done yet, so this
> Bugzilla looks more like a "should I do an article" rather than "I have an
> article for review". Let me know if I am incorrect.

Nope, that's it. I'd like to write an article, but I'd rather not spend the time unless I know someone's interested in this.
It sounds like a useful idea to me.
I'm also interested. Thanks for considering taking the time.
It looks like we have enough interest to take this to the next level. When can you have a first draft?

As far as I can tell, I'll be able to spend the next weekend entirely on the article - I'll try to prepare a first draft for sunday evening (CEST, that is). I'll try to settle on a consistent structure first and then start to fill in the details. I can't really estimate how complete the first estimate will be.

first preliminary version

First rough outline and some bits of text - in plain text format because I still haven't grokked this DocBook thing ;-)

Please don't bother to review the technical details yet, I still have to fill too many gaps. However, it would be great to know whether I've got the "detail level" right - did I include too many technical details or too few? Apart from the "big picture" introduction at the beginning and the spots marked with TODO, are any other important parts missing?

Created an attachment (id=73221)
draft of article with associated files

I've uploaded an almost completed version of the article. One technical issue still needs resolving (waiting for reply on the GMF newsgroup), and the acknowledgements still need work, but the rest of the article is now more or less what I had in mind. I've included the screenshots and zip files as well. The layout might still need some work, as well as the text itself - I'm not a native speaker. I'd appreciate any comments on this draft.

I can help with spelling/grammar issues. If other reviewers can focus on content, that'd be great (of course, fixing spelling and grammar is also helpful).

If nobody on the CC list can review, we'll have to try a little harder to find somebody. Any volunteers?

I had a *very* brief look and it seems good at a glance, but I don't have the time to follow this in detail.  I wish I did.  :-(  It would be ideal if one of the many interested parties had the time to review this and to try out the scenarios to test them...

What versions of EMF and GMF do you use? In the last few month a lot changed in GMF. Is it really necessary to store the diagram information together with the semantic model? This is really bad, because you one might want to have multiple graphical representations (ind multiple diagrams) of one sematic element. This is necessary to show different aspects of the semantic model (e.g. the hirarchy  in one diagram, the containment or the associations in an other one).

Mathias,

As far as I understand it, the semantic model can either be stored with the diagram model or separate from it; this question is often asked on the GMF newsgroup, i.e., it's kind of a FAQ although not in the FAQ, which is quite sparse: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Graphical_Modeling_Framework_FAQ

(In reply to comment #12)
> What versions of EMF and GMF do you use? 

The ones provided with the Release - EMF 2.3.0, GEF 3.3.0, GMF 2.0.

> In the last few month a lot changed in GMF. 

I know - I was partly a "victim" of these changes because I had to use the milestones for my bachelor thesis. :-)

> Is it really necessary to store the diagram information together with 
> the semantic model? This is really bad, because you one might want to 
> have multiple graphical representations (ind multiple diagrams) of one 
> sematic element. This is necessary to show different aspects of the 
> semantic model (e.g. the hirarchy in one diagram, the containment or 
> the associations in an other one). 

I get your point, and I can see the benefits - however, I think this would require a more complex approach because you have to find out what other resources to load and distribute the inputs to the EditorParts. Interesting question...

I'm a big fan of this initiative, since we're trying to do something similar here at work. The article has started great, and I'm offering my limited experience to get this work up to speed.

I have tried to follow the steps to combine my two editors and have some comments, which I hope is okay to share this way.

Consider mentioning the change made for the selection viewer in handleContentOutlineSelection:
	// If it's the selection viewer, then we want it to select the same selection as this selection.
	//
	if (getActiveEditor() == selectionEditorPart) {

Consider listing current known problems with (or open issues of) this solution, similar to Open Issues in http://www.volker-wegert.de/emf-gmf-integration

Running on the Europa release (feature versions listed at the bottom of this posting), I experienced the following problems with the "final state" version of the example:
- When clicking the Diagram page tab to bring up the TopicMap Diagram Editor, and when after that clicking an item in the outline, an exception occurs:
	java.lang.ClassCastException: org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.diagram.part.TopicMapDiagramEditor
		at org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.presentation.TopicmapEditor.handleContentOutlineSelection(TopicmapEditor.java:1087)
  Perhaps a guard that the active editor isn't diagramEditor could be used.
- A stack overflow occurs when creating a Topic (or an Association) in the TopicMap Diagram Editor
	Unhandled event loop exception
	java.lang.StackOverflowError
		at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.internalWorked(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:94)
		at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.internalWorked(SubProgressMonitor.java:155)
		at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.internalWorked(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:94)
		at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.internalWorked(SubProgressMonitor.java:155)
		...
   It seems objects are created in an endless loop. The TopicCreateCommand is created in a single instance but executed in the endless loop.

Regards
J?rgen Strandberg

Updated draft - the typo mentioned in comment #22 is fixed, and the stack overflow is gone, too. Many thanks to Alex for helping out on various issues.

I'm not sure what would be different for "an RCP version" of this article, but I'd be glad to get the article completed in the first place. As for this being integrated into the standard GMF tools - this is way (WAY) outside of what I could accomplish. If you want this, you're probably better off filing your own bug/enhancement request for this.

In the article it would be better to move the css in the same folder of the HTML.

In a RCP version, beside extending org.eclipse.core.runtime.applications, you have to avoid all dependencies to ide plugins, so avoid e.g. 
IFileEditorInput
FileEditorInputProxy
ResourcesPlugin

I hope this help to improve your good article. I just add my vote.
In EMF 2.3 we added EditUIUtil.getURI(IEditorInput) that's very handy for processing many types of editor input in the same way and still have it work for RCP and IDE.

And I should probably mention that EMF does generate an RCP editor:

http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-EMF-goes-RCP/rcp.html

I just suspect that GMF doesn't support RCP, but I could be wrong...

(In reply to comment #26)
> And I should probably mention that EMF does generate an RCP editor:
> http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-EMF-goes-RCP/rcp.html
> I just suspect that GMF doesn't support RCP, but I could be wrong...

GMF support RCP. If you use GMF Dashboard, check RCP and you'll have "Gen Application TopicmapApplication" under Gen Editor in gmfgen file.

I'm trying your code (Eclipse 3.3 and 3.4 with last Milestone), but TopicmapEditor doesn't appear because TopicMapDiagramEditor is registered as Editor for the same extension and in my case takes precedence. So in
-------------------------------------------
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.editors">
      <?gmfgen generated="true"?>
      <editor
         id="org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.diagram.part.TopicMapDiagramEditorID"
         name="%editorName"
         icon="icons/obj16/TopicmapDiagramFile.gif"
*********************************
         extensions="topicmap2"
**********************************
         default="true"
         class="org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.diagram.part.TopicMapDiagramEditor"
         matchingStrategy="org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.diagram.part.TopicMapMatchingStrategy"
         contributorClass="org.example.emfgmf.topicmap.diagram.part.TopicMapDiagramActionBarContributor">
      </editor>
   </extension>
----------------------------------------

change extension name or better remove this extension.

Anyway I'm not so expert in EMF and less in GMF, so I must study a way to see in the tree view (Selection) only the semantic part of the model, because for the notation part you should use only the Diagram page of the editor.

In your article I read:
---------------------------
 Change the property Same File for Diagram And Model to true and change diagram file extension to match the domain file extension - if you skip this, things will get a bit more complicated later
-------------------------------------

but it miss an implementation with two distinct file, this way the wizard "Topicmap model" would not generate the error  "Resource contains no diagram".
I didn't know they used that pattern.  For RCP that pattern would require the use of the Eclipse resource APIs and RCP applications don't typically use a workspace.

(In reply to comment #29)
> what should I use?
I suppose corresponding part of the article should be changed in near future. 
For RCP application you can use URIEditorInput (as in the generated code) and I suggest creating your own EditorInput holding EditingDomaininstalce inside. This EditorInput should be passed to DiagramEditor as a parameter of setInput() method.

You should be able to right-click the file in the explorer and choose the editor you want to use by selecting "Open with". 

> Anyway I'm not so expert in EMF and less in GMF, so I must study a way to see
> in the tree view (Selection) only the semantic part of the model, because for
> the notation part you should use only the Diagram page of the editor.

See TopicmapEditor.getContentOutlinePage - you will probably have to hand a different content provider to the contentOutlineViewer.

> In your article I read:
> ---------------------------
>  Change the property Same File for Diagram And Model to true and change diagram
> file extension to match the domain file extension - if you skip this, things
> will get a bit more complicated later
> -------------------------------------
> 
> but it miss an implementation with two distinct file, this way the wizard
> "Topicmap model" would not generate the error  "Resource contains no diagram".

Yep, but you would have to read multiple files, wrap them up in some Resource and distribute things nicely among the editors. It's not impossible, just way more complicated. I originally set out to outline the principle, not to deliver a solution.

To be honest, I'd like to get this article finished ASAP - I'll see what I can do during the next days. I'm not sure whether we (Alex and I) will be able to cover every aspect of the integration in detail, but that's why we're writing an article and not a book. I have yet to see any Eclipse Corner article that does not leave some questions waiting to be answered. I could very well imagine this article not touching the entire RCP scenario and leaving something to write for someone who knows more about this :-)

Nice article, helpful suggestions.

Unfortunately, it doesn't extend to a TextEditor or multiple diagram editors.

The first problem is that existing editors may be part of an existing EditorPart inheritance hierarchy and so cannot all extend the shared concrete TopicMapEditorPart.

For my UMLX editor which has multi-sheet diagrams/trees/text and a multiplicity of saveable files, I introduced an additional IPageManager hierarchy to mediate between the MultiPageEditorPart and the individual EditorParts. The amorphous handleContentOutlineSelection can be resolved by activePageManager.setSelectionFromOutline(). Problems with diverse undoContexts and save-abilities can be similarly delegated.

The second problem is that you have to fudge getting the tabbed properties to work. Your fudge is fine for a narrow EMF extension of GMF, but is there any way to make tabbed properties extensible? For instance if I want to have an application that supports two different independent third party diagram editors, I cannot have my composite application offer the contributorId of both contributions, so only one of the property sets can work, and I have to put my properties into the contributorId of the one that I want to work. It seems that an editor needs to be able to offer a list of contributorIds; one for each re-used contribution and one for the re-using contribution.

A page change is not a transaction in the generated EMF editor, so it is not reversed during an undo. This is at least surprising when you undo a sequence of commands and don't have the appropriate diagram/tree in which to view the changes.

[The above comments are perhaps more applicable to version 2 or an article on integrating EMF + GMF + Text editors. Ideally, the EMF generated editor would advance to avoid the need for many of your solutions.]

Heading for the first final farewell tour, I hope - this draft is what Alex and I think might be close to the final version of the article. Whatever additional reviews and adaptions are still necessary, please tell us. We don't really feel like extending the article beyond its current size (it's already more than twice as big as the original draft) or taking many more options into consideration, or we might as well start on that book. ;-)

Thanks to Alex and Volker for this great article!

I read through 75% of the article and have some comments:
1) Contains german word: "and list- oder tree-based"
2) Word 'editor' is misspelled: "arbitrary multi-page e ditor"
3) Missing 'n' in many: "there are may use cases"
4) Missing 'i' in "capabilites"
5) ?? "from a scratch" should be "from scratch"
6) Please include the @generated tag in the source code example as bold text, so the user notices it when browsing the source.
   "Don't forget to set the @generated tag"
7) Misspelled: "Fortinately"
8) General: you're using a lot of "(un)fortunately"s

Again, many thanks to all you guys for writing this. I'd love to try that out next time I need a EMF/GEF editor.
